Introduction

Specific phobia is characterized by a persistent, intense fear of an object or situation that causes significant distress or functional impairment and is out of proportion with the actual danger or risk associated with the object or situation.  Specific phobia often results in panic symptoms and avoidance behaviors.

Epidemiology and risk factors



Specific phobia is common, with an estimated lifetime prevalence of approximately 10%.  Women are more frequently affected than men (2:1 ratio), and onset is typically during childhood.



Several factors may increase the likelihood of developing specific phobia, including traits such as neuroticism (predisposition to negative affects) and behavioral inhibition (tendency to avoid or experience distress from novel or unfamiliar situations).  Additional risk factors include parental overprotectiveness, parental loss and separation, adverse childhood events (eg, neglect, abuse), and stressful or traumatic life events (eg, intimate partner violence).

Pathogenesis



The pathogenesis of specific phobia is unclear, although it may involve:



  • Having a parent or caregiver reinforce that certain objects or situations are dangerous and need to be avoided (eg, child being told that all dogs are dangerous and to stay away from them)
  • Observing a parent or caregiver reacting in a fearful way to phobic stimulus (eg, parent has a fearful reaction to dogs and avoids them)
  • Witnessing another person have a traumatic or frightening experience (eg, seeing someone be bitten by a dog)
  • Having a personal experience of a frightening situation that results in fear associated with that object or situation (eg, being bitten by a dog during childhood)

Clinical presentation



Specific phobias can be related to any object or situation (phobic stimulus), and they are categorized as follows:



  • Animal (eg, spiders, insects, dogs)
  • Natural environment (eg, heights, water, thunderstorms)
  • Blood-injection-injury (eg, needles, surgical or dental procedures)
  • Situational (eg, airplanes, elevators)
  • Other (eg, vomiting, clowns)


Anxiety symptoms are experienced immediately in anticipation, or in the presence, of the feared situation or object (symptoms are not delayed and do not occur randomly).  The severity of symptoms and the resulting functional impairment depend on the proximity and frequency in which the phobic situation or object is encountered (eg, a patient with a phobia of snakes who lives in the city rarely experiences symptoms, whereas a patient who fears dogs and lives in a dog-friendly apartment building has daily symptoms).



Fear responses involve activation of the sympathetic nervous system, resulting in physical symptoms that are consistent with panic attacks (eg, palpitations, dyspnea, sweatiness).  With blood-injection-injury phobias, there may be an initial increase in heart rate and blood pressure followed by a fainting or near-fainting episode.  Children often express fear by crying, freezing, clinging to parents or caregivers, or engaging in behavioral outbursts or tantrums.



Patients with specific phobia actively avoid the feared situation or object.  Work-arounds are incorporated into daily life (eg, driving an extra 20 minutes daily to avoid crossing a bridge) to prevent or reduce contact with what they fear.  Significant life decisions may be made based on avoiding a phobic stimulus (eg, moving to an area where earthquakes are unlikely to occur, choosing a job that does not require travel).  If avoidance of the phobic stimulus is not possible, it is experienced with significant distress.



Patients recognize that their fears are irrational and disproportionate, which may reinforce avoidance behaviors and result in shame or embarrassment.

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of specific phobia, the following criteria must be met:



  • Marked fear or anxiety about a specific object or situation (eg, flying, heights, animals) occurs.  In children, this may be expressed by crying, tantrums, freezing, or clinging to a parent or caregiver.
  • The phobic object or situation almost always provokes immediate fear or anxiety.
  • The phobic object or situation is actively avoided or endured with intense fear or anxiety.
  • The fear or anxiety is out of proportion with the actual danger posed by the specific object or situation.
  • The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, typically lasting â‰¥6 months.
  • The fear, anxiety, or avoidance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
  • The fear or anxiety is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder.

Differential diagnosis



  • Developmentally appropriate fears:  very common and tend to remit with age (eg, toddler who is fearful of the dark); fears, unlike phobias, tend to improve with distraction and reassurance and do not impair daily functioning
  • Social anxiety disorder:  involves intense fear and specific avoidance of social interactions; a fear of being judged or negatively evaluated by others (eg, seen as boring or unlikable) must also be present
  • Panic disorder:  involves panic attacks that are spontaneous, unprovoked, and without an identifiable trigger
  • Agoraphobia:  involves situation-specific panic symptoms and avoidance; however, multiple situations are involved (eg, crowds and enclosed spaces), and the fears consist of not being able to escape or of help being unavailable if panic or other incapacitating symptoms develop
  • Generalized anxiety disorder:  presents with excessive worry and panic attacks; however, the anxiety is diffuse (related to multiple topics such as finances, relationships, and health), not circumscribed to a specific situation or object

Evaluation and diagnostic work-up



A thorough history (including prior mood episodes, substance use, and family psychiatric disorders) and physical examination are necessary to determine the likelihood of specific phobia versus other medical or psychiatric conditions that may present similarly or coincide with a specific phobia (eg, cardiovascular disease, alcohol withdrawal, panic disorder).



Depending on clinical findings, a diagnostic work-up may be indicated for conditions that can present with panic symptoms (eg, pulmonary embolism, pheochromocytoma, transient ischemic attack).

Management



The management of specific phobia is guided by the frequency and severity of symptoms.  For phobic stimuli that are rarely encountered and do not result in significant avoidance behaviors, treatment may not be necessary or benzodiazepine taken as needed may be sufficient.  For patients with more severe symptoms, avoidance behaviors, and functional impairment, first-line treatment includes psychotherapy or benzodiazepines:



  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) with exposure:

    • CBT with exposure targets maladaptive thoughts and avoidance behavior through gradual exposure to the feared situation or object to extinguish the fear response (eg, may start with reading a book about thunderstorms, then progress to listening to audio or watching a video of a thunderstorm).
    • Patients may be reluctant to engage in exposure therapy given avoidance behaviors, and multiple conversations may be necessary to discuss the steps of therapy and address patient questions and concerns.
  • Benzodiazepines (eg, clonazepam, lorazepam):
    • Intended for patients whose condition declines or who do not have access to CBT with exposure
    • Recommended for phobic stimuli that are less frequently encountered (eg, traveling by airplane 3 times a year)
    • Avoided for patients engaging in exposure therapy (may dampen the ability to experience anxiety and decrease the efficacy of treatment)


Many patients have a comorbid psychiatric condition, such as mood, anxiety, substance use, or personality (eg, dependent personality) disorders.  Therefore, appropriate screening and treatment are recommended.

Prognosis



The prognosis of patients with a specific phobia can vary; if untreated, phobias are likely to be chronic and lifelong.  Depending on how frequently the phobic stimulus is encountered, there may be significant functional impairment and decreased quality of life.  The majority of patients who complete exposure therapy experience improvement or remission of symptoms.
